Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> but this is the first time it will come to the masses

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> right, and we have no interest in making secret targeting of VerusHash something that is rewarded. open targeting of VerusHash is a completely different story, especially for those who are interested in making an actual decentralized system

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> having hardware that provides great increases in performance doesn't increase centralization

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> the secret part i can agree with

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> so people got their rewards for secretly mining. now we can all start over and see how to do things correctly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> but you can't attribute large incremental increases in technology capabilities with decentralization

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> variation and availability is what provides decentralization

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> and if it happens again, the secret part, there are lots of knobs and dials on the new algo that any good dev who deals with them this time around will understand. no need to be secret about it. there's even an immediate reward not to be, and if we can work to cooperate together, if there is a future algo change, it can be something we do together. if that can't be, then it can't, but we would like to try.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> and i get what your saying, i just dont like people using the term decentralization as a metric to push off fpga's like its a monopoly like bitmain etc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> your network hash could be comprised of some huge farms of gpu's, that is centralization

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> thats the same for any coin

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> adding any other hardware to the system that is owned by miners everywhere helps to prevent centralization

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> but at the end of the day majority of miners mine what is profitable

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> if you only had miners on your network that truly believed in your coin, you'd have a small centralized network

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i could have bricked the 325t chip that F1 one uses if that was our decision. it wasn't, and i hope i didn't. our initial hope was to get cooperation on the plan, but without that, I tried hard to make sure they could still implement the algo, though with a significantly smaller gap between CPUs, GPUs, and FPGAs than there has been. until someone really does follow the algo, we won't know, but as there is more than one party wanting to, I guess we will see soon enough.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> ya a lot of unknowns, i'll definitely keep an eye on the space

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> its always a slippery slope when you see coins fork a month after finding new hardware on their network

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> if you're a dev, look at the algo. this wasn't a knee jerk fork. it was very purposeful and the algo was designed for that purpose. we just tend to work quickly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> you guys found out about 2 weeks after the algo was released

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i don't think so

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> i started mining it at release

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> its only been out about 5-6 week now

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> i could find the exact date

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> the moment you guys found out about it, everyone in your network had the ability to buy an F!

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> it was no longer secret

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i started suspecting before that, and by the time it was sure, it was clear that the suspicions were likely accurate when it started. i'm pretty sure i know when it started being used, and it was a bit more than a couple weeks

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> looks like its been about 7 weeks

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> according to my stats

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> so not that long

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> you guys found out about a month ago?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> publicly i should say

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> 4-5 weeks?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Cruz> @uchirosan  What's the point you are trying to make, with this conversation?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> i'm having a conversation with him, not about a point

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> we're just conversing

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> we could not recommend that people buy Blackminer's F1 that was potentially going to be bricked without a deal, and the community wanted this approach. i think it's actually quite reasonable, and i look forward to the first FPGA implementations. very curious how the algo will be solved, which is why we are willing to help FPGA devs. we have no illusions that we will stay immune to custom hardware forever. we just want to get there as a community, not by being sniped from the side.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> nobody has to make a point in a convo, you can gain valuable insight into thought processes and clearer understanding

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Cruz> No problem. I was just curious.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> i do understand that @miketout

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> like i said, i dont agree with secret mining

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> its a double edged sword

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i also understand your point

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> most coins/devs are incentivized by the current hardware scheme

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> having a piece of hardware that drastically changes the eco system playing field can cause a stir

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> and part of the reason why some want to go in secretly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> not saying its right or wrong

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> in fact, given this response, there is a scenario where it turns out only to be positive, but I hope the person behind the secret mining strategy finds another vocation. i don't think this is the way to get millions of people to buy FPGAs, which is the only thing that will allow them to help with decentralization.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> if they had come to you and said, we have a piece of hardware that is 20x greater than what you currently have; what would you have said?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> most gpu miners that want to fight against fpga's and asics is because theyve invested heavily into gpu's and have suffered the market losses and can't afford new hardware

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> so they dont want said new hardware coming into the space

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> we are going to see sub $1k fpga's early in 2019 and $500 fpga's shortly thereafter

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i think 20x creates a problem, and i would have wanted to work with them on an algo change to close the gap while not preventing their miner to have an advantage as a professional tool that was specialized enough to economically deserve a premium. in fact, that is exactly what we tried to work out

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> in a market where profits are next to nothing, fpga's can be the saving grace of the mining spher

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> not at all

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> what is the current hashrate on your algo on cpu and gpu?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> that argument is exactly the same as saying "there isn't enough to satisfy everyone who wants to participate, so just let a small number of people take more"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> you can look in the CPU hashrate channel. people are posting

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> no,but stalling progress to help those that have hardware at the same of progression is just as bad

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> there is no stalling of progress

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> i would disagree with you there, the fact that you feel liek 20x performance on next gen hardware is too much and want to artificially bring it down is stalling progress

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> thats saying, this new hardware is too fast relative to older hardware

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> so we need to bring it down

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> but i also see your point of view as well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> I don't mean to butt in but I just wanted to add that in a system that is so young and where fpgas are not spread out or even known about it's hard to introduce them into a system with such huge electrical efficiencies where there is no small  connection  to price and price can be dropped down when a large Supply is controled

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> It is good for progress

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> introducing fpga's to the market does nothing to coin prices

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> the only argument that it is good is an argument that centralization is the cure to not enough mining profits. people are still mining with that advantage now, and if FPGAs follow the fork and cannot be faster than CPUs, it won't be because we wouldn't have cooperated to make that possible. it will be because we were not given that option. if we end up in a spot where FPGAs are definitely slower, we may actually consider a fork at the next natural point to do the opposite.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> It's just not going on across the entire Market

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> for those that have mined long enough ,we saw the same arguments from devs when gpu's starting taking the stage:)

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> and then again with asics

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> though asics were slanted towards the manufacturers and not what the hardware could do

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> we were one of the only coins that made GPU and CPU mining work together on the network. FPGAs took advantage of a weakness in the algo, they didn't introduce some amazing new advance.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> the algo was simply too small

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> they dont typically introduce an amazing advance

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> in many ways

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> they just have the power to mine faster and more efficiently without being a door stop like an asic

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> really the best of both worlds in mining

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> and i'm a gpu miner for many many years

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> and i swapped over to a number of fpga's because it made sense to do so

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> in a time when efficiency can mean no profits or some profits

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> the idea that someone can mine more efficiently with more efficient hardware is a fallacy. it's all relative

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> if everyone had FPGAs, they would be decentralizing, and they would not provide any advantage

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> its not relative, a 1080ti uses a certain amount of power to mine a certain hash at a certain hardware cost

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> right

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> a product that can mine more coins, with less power with a better hash/hardware cost is more efficient

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> but people will use more FPGAs and more electricity until they reach the amount they will spend

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> no because fpga's cost more as well

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> to compete at the level of their willingness to invest

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> if your buidling a $2500 gpu rig

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> i'm talking long term

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> vs a 2500 fpga

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> which one is more efficient for the cost?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> the only argument that they are more efficient is a relative argument

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> power usage isn't relative

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> its constant

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> that is a relative question

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> POW makes it constant

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> power usage will go up when everyone has the same hardware to the same willingness to invest

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> majority of people selling their gpu's would disagree with you

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <uchirosan> those same people could buy an fpga and still be mining for the same upfront cost
